text:
We do this - we made an internal case study based on our own social media metrics showing the difference before and after an internal employee advocacy initiative. We then took those results and made them into a slide deck we use for new clients to show them results of employee engagement.

It’s all in the data and if you have access to yours it’s a really impactful aid for a presentation.

Then, we booked a weekly 30 minute meeting to give everyone a chance to meet on a call and spend a few minutes engaging with our internal content and each other’s thought leadership content.

The results have been :rocket: Hope this helps!

text:
Hi @channel looking for advice:
Trying to build awareness in my B2B SAAS company’s niche and industry verticals. One tactic we’re considering investing in is PR, with a firm promising a lot of things. 
Any advice on what to watch out for? And best way to approach content with them? 

(I am director of Growth - content marketing background, only a small amount of PR experience).

elements.text:
Hi @channel looking for advice:
Trying to build awareness in my B2B SAAS company’s niche and industry verticals. One tactic we’re considering investing in is PR, with a firm promising a lot of things. 
Any advice on what to watch out for? And best way to approach content with them?
(I am director of Growth - content marketing background, only a small amount of PR experience).

text: Hi <@U01N6FU06G4>. I am only speaking from my experience and viewpoint but PR would be more relevant for product or service releases or company announcements in my eyes. Ideally with SaaS it's more important to build the rapport as an industry leader for your niche to increase the marketable of the company alongside of it's products and services. Awareness building also involves getting your audience, clients, and protentional clients more heavily involved on a more personal level. One way I did this on a corporate level in the past was by have town halls/webinars with a slotted open forum timeframes for sme's to answer questions related to pain points and concerns of the audience.
